summary: This is an FBI internal request form from the Miami Division to the Records Management Division and Special Technologies and Applications Office, requesting scanning, automation, and data formatting assistance for telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The document reveals Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager, attempted to sell an address book believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein; subject of obstruction of justice case
persons.context: The subject of the FBI's obstruction of justice investigation. He allegedly came into possession of an address book with names and numbers of potential underage victims of Epstein and attempted to sell it.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Identified as the individual whose former house manager, Alfredo Rodriguez, possessed an address book believed to contain information on his additional underage victims.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez came into possession of an address book believed to contain information on Epstein's potential underage victims, connecting him to the core of the Epstein investigation.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Alfredo Rodriguez
events.description: The Miami Division of the FBI opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager.

events.title: Rodriguez attempts to sell victim address book
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez attempted to sell an address book containing names and telephone numbers of what are believed to be additional underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein to an Undercover Employee (UCE), rather than turning it over to law enforcement or attorneys in response to federal subpoenas.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager and butler, was the subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009.
Rodriguez came into possession of an address book believed to contain names and telephone numbers of additional, previously unknown underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez attempted to sell this address book to an FBI Undercover Employee (UCE) instead of complying with federal subpoenas to turn it over to law enforcement or attorneys.
The FBI's 'Baleen Sweep' project was processing telephone records obtained from the address book, believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims.

This document is an internal FBI request for technical assistance to scan, automate, and format these telephone records for analysis and incorporation into the Bureau's investigative database (Telephone Application - TA).
